title: Can I also use proceeds from the Trust to pay my personal expenses, like legal fees, while using probate proceeds for tax debt?
question: I am the sole Trustee and Executor of my mother's estate (d. Jan 2015). My father predeceased her. Most of her assets (house, cars, jewelry, art, etc) were in a Trust except for one IRA account that must go through probate because she neglected to list a beneficiary other than my father. There are some outstanding tax and other debts that need to be paid. I am planning to keep her house, refinance it and pull some money out to make some repairs and then use it as a rental. I was told I need two taxpayer IDs, one for the trust assets and one for the probate assets. I was planning to use the assets from the probate accounts to pay off the remaining debts from the estate.
answers: Talk to an attorney about whether a Heggstad petition would be appropriate to vest the IRA to the trust. If that's the only asset to be probated, it would save you the time and bother of opening a separate probate. Your question doesn't say whether you're the sole beneficiary.

Yes the trust assets can be used to pay for out of pocket expenses for the trust administration. Legal fees can be paid from the account to go through probate. Tax debt can be paid from the trust account on the real property. If income taxes are due on the probated estate, that would come from the IRA account. Are you sure that the IRA account can't be put into the trust via what is called a Hegsted petition?

Yes. Separate taxpayer ID's required for trust and probate estate.
You will need to pay probate creditors before you close the probate matter.
Yes. You may use amount distributed to you for any purpose you wish. Upon distribution, the funds belong to you.
You may find following link useful:
https://www.irs.gov/Businesses/Small-Businesses-&-Self-Employed/Deceased-Taxpayers-Filing-the-Estate-Income-Tax-Return-Form-10
